misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points rather than reading a single numeric grade (0–100) and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges, so it does not address the problem specification at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read two coordinate points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and print their distance, as in a distance-formula problem, rather than to classify a numeric grade into a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine whether it falls in the A (90–100), B (80–89), C (70–79), D (60–69), or F (<60) range, and finally print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
No conditional statements or Boolean range checks are present
Output reports the distance between two points, not a letter grade
No handling of grade ranges A–F at all
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of code from a previous distance-formula exercise without adapting it to the current grade-mapping specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program to: (1) read one numeric grade; (2) use an if-else chain to test which range (A, B, C, D, F) the grade falls into; and (3) print the appropriate letter grade instead of a distance.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around computing a distance between points with no trace of grade input or letter-grade logic, which strongly indicates misunderstanding of the task.

evidence.note: All input and computation are devoted to reading two coordinate points and computing their distance, with no code for reading a grade or mapping it to a letter.

misconceptions.name: Code implements wrong problem/task
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (Distance Formula) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are implementing a program to calculate the distance between two points, perhaps confusing this problem with another assignment, or submitting the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to write a Grade Calculator program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade.
Code calculates Euclidean distance.
Code output is 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
No conditional logic (if/else if) is present to map grades to letter grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the required task, submission of incorrect code, or major conceptual error regarding the assignment's goal.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt for Q3. Delete the current code and start fresh, focusing only on the Grade Calculator logic (input one grade, use if/else if to determine the letter output).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates distance using (x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2 and prints 'The distance of the two points is...', which conclusively demonstrates a failure to address the specified problem (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: Variables are declared for calculating distance between two points, not for a single grade.
Input is four coordinates, not a single grade.

evidence.snippet:
d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Code calculates distance and outputs a message unrelated to grade calculation.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a distance calculator between two points instead of a grade calculator. This shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade conversion problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and converting it to a letter grade (A-F). Instead, the student is reading four coordinates and calculating Euclidean distance.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Code calculates distance using the Euclidean distance formula
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Output displays distance, not letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either worked on the wrong problem, copied code from a different assignment, or completely misread the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: 1) Read ONE numeric grade (0-100), 2) Use if-else statements to check grade ranges (90-100=A, 80-89=B, etc.), 3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code implements a completely different algorithm (Euclidean distance) than what was requested (grade conversion). This is not a minor error but a fundamental mismatch between the problem and solution.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates Euclidean distance between two points, not grade conversion. This is the wrong problem entirely.
Prompts for coordinates instead of a grade value (should be 'Enter grade:')

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Outputs distance instead of letter grade (should output 'Letter grade: A/B/C/D/F')

misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong program (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter-grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs A–F based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and prints the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a numeric grade.
No conditional logic checking grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Output reports a distance value rather than a letter grade.
None of the rubric criteria (grade input, boolean ranges, handling F, letter output) are attempted.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment instructions or copying the solution for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design a program that reads one numeric grade value, then uses if/else-if/else statements to compare it against the specified ranges and print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
Basic program design from a specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, variables, and computation clearly match a distance-formula problem and contain no elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: The code reads two coordinate pairs and computes a distance; it does not read a grade or produce any letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have implemented a solution for a previous or unrelated programming task (distance formula) and submitted it for the Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads multiple inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Code calculates Euclidean distance.
Output is a distance calculation, not a letter grade.
No conditional logic (if/else statements) is present to perform grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted code for the wrong assignment or completely misinterpreted the prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description for 'Q3. Grade Calculator' and implement the required logic using Scanner for input and conditional statements (if/else if/else) for grading.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence; the code implements the distance formula exactly, which is completely irrelevant to the grade calculator task.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade, demonstrating complete failure to meet the input requirements for the assignment.

evidence.snippet:
d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The core function of the submitted code is calculating the distance formula, not assigning a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance calculator) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this distance calculator code solves the grade calculator assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges. The submitted code solves a different problem entirely.
symptoms: Code reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted incorrect code—either wrong file, misread assignment, or copied from wrong solution attempt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q3 assignment carefully. Write new code that: (1) reads a single numeric grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence—the code is objectively solving a different problem. No part of this solution addresses grade calculation.

evidence.note: Code reads two pairs of coordinates and calculates Euclidean distance—not a grade input/grade classification.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Output statement prints a distance value, not a letter grade mapping.
